title: Francesco Rocca
text:
Francesco Rocca (; born 2 August 1954) is an Italian professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> coach and former player, who played as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">defender</a>. He spent his entire career with Italian club <a href="A.S.%20Roma">Roma</a>, where he won the <a href="Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a> twice. He was the coach of the <a href="Italy%20national%20under-20%20football%20team">Italy national under-20 football team</a> from 2008 until 2011. He also led the <a href="Italy%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Italy Olympic side</a> to a fourth-place ranking at the <a href="Football%20at%20the%201988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a>.
Club career.
Born in the <a href="San%20Vito%20Romano">San Vito Romano</a> village 40 km from <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, Rocca played his club football exclusively for <a href="A.S.%20Roma">Roma</a> from 1972 to 1981. Rocca played 163 games for Roma, including 141 games in <a href="Serie%20A">Serie A</a> and 22 in the <a href="Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a> cup – winning the later competition for two consecutive years between 1980 and 1981 – but did not score any goals for the club.
International career.
Rocca played 18 games for the <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy national football team</a> from 1974 to 1976, and scored a goal for Italy against the <a href="United%20States%20men%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">United States national soccer team</a>.
At the age of 26, a serious injury forced Rocca to retire.
Managerial career.
As a manager, Rocca took Italy to a fourth place at the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympics">1988 Summer Olympics</a>. He also led the <a href="Italy%20national%20under-19%20football%20team">U-19 team</a> which finished as the runner-up in the <a href="2008%20UEFA%20European%20Under-19%20Football%20Championship">2008 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship</a>. After the tournament he changed to being a coach of the U-20 team, and led his team to the <a href="2009%20FIFA%20U-20%20World%20Cup">2009 FIFA U-20 World Cup</a>.
He is one of eleven members of the Hall of Fame of <a href="A.S.%20Roma">A.S. Roma</a>.
Style of play.
Rocca was nicknamed "<a href="Kawasaki%20%28motorbike%29">Kawasaki</a>" (after the Japanese brand of motor bikes) because of his pace, work-rate, energy, and durability in the <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Left-back">left-back</a> position; he was also an accurate <a href="Cross%20%28football%29">crosser</a> of the ball.
